importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The start date of the last government shutdown, which lasted 35 days and was the longest in nearly 50 years.
The end date of the last government shutdown, marking a 35-day closure that cost the U.S. an estimated $3 billion in lost GDP.
The beginning of a policy shift in which federal agencies were instructed to halt operations during funding lapses, setting precedent for future shutdowns.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: This 35-day period was the longest government shutdown in history and had significant economic consequences, including a $3 billion loss in GDP.
The current government shutdown, as of the article's update, is still ongoing with no passage of the 12 appropriations bills, indicating a full shutdown.

keyTakeAways: The last government shutdown in the U.S. lasted 35 days, from December 22, 2018, to January 25, 2019, making it the longest in nearly 50 years.
This shutdown cost the U.S. economy an estimated $3 billion in lost GDP according to the Congressional Budget Office (CBO).
The first federal government shutdown occurred in 1976, and since then, federal agencies have been instructed to cease operations during funding lapses.
Since 1990, there have been six government shutdowns, indicating a recurring political stalemate, especially in a highly partisan environment.
The current shutdown is a full shutdown, unlike the 2018 event which was partial — meaning all federal operations are halted without funding, including pay for employees.
During the 2018 shutdown, approximately 800,000 federal employees were affected, with about 300,000 furloughed and 500,000 exempted but unpaid.
The current Congress has failed to pass any of the 12 required appropriations bills, resulting in the ongoing full government shutdown.
Republican Speaker Mike Johnson oversees a narrow House majority, and the GOP lacks the 60 votes needed to end a Senate filibuster, making negotiations difficult.
The shutdown highlights deep political divisions and institutional challenges in Congress, particularly in spending negotiations.

namedEntities.name: Kaanita Iyer

namedEntities.name: CNN
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: CNN is the source of the article, providing a trusted media outlet for public access to information about government shutdowns.

namedEntities.name: Congressional Budget Office (CBO)
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The CBO provides official estimates of economic impact, such as the $3 billion GDP loss from the 2018 shutdown.

namedEntities.name: Mike Johnson
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Mike Johnson, as Republican Speaker of the House, plays a key role in shaping legislative outcomes and influencing the current shutdown's duration and negotiation path.

namedEntities.name: Senate filibuster
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The filibuster prevents the Senate from passing legislation unless 60 votes are secured, which the GOP currently lacks, blocking spending deals and contributing to the shutdown.

namedEntities.name: United States federal government
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The federal government's ongoing shutdown reflects systemic political dysfunction and economic consequences for citizens and businesses.

namedEntities.name: 12 appropriations bills
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The failure to pass these bills is the direct cause of the current full government shutdown.

namedEntities.name: December 22, 2018
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Start date of the last major government shutdown, which lasted 35 days and set a record in history.

namedEntities.name: January 25, 2019
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: End date of the 2018 shutdown, marking the conclusion of the longest shutdown in nearly 50 years.
The year when the first federal government shutdown occurred, establishing a historical baseline for future events.
A period when federal agencies began being instructed to stop operations during funding lapses, influencing future shutdown protocols.

namedEntities.name: 35 days
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The length of the 2018 shutdown, which remains the longest in history and serves as a benchmark for current events.

namedEntities.name: $3 billion
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The estimated GDP loss from the 2018 shutdown, highlighting economic consequences of political gridlock.

namedEntities.name: 300,000 furloughed
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The number of federal employees not paid and asked not to report to work during the 2018 shutdown.

namedEntities.name: 500,000 exempted
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The number of employees who were required to report to work but not paid during the 2018 shutdown.

namedEntities.name: full government shutdown
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The current state of the U.S. government, where no appropriations bills have passed, affecting all federal operations.

namedEntities.name: partial shutdown
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The type of shutdown that occurred in 2018, where only certain agencies had funding, distinguishing it from the current full shutdown.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The U.S. is experiencing a full government shutdown due to Congress failing to pass the required 12 appropriations bills, marking a continuation of political gridlock. The last major shutdown, which began on December 22, 2018, lasted 35 days — the longest in nearly 50 years — and cost the economy an estimated $3 billion in lost GDP. During that event, about 300,000 employees were furloughed and 500,000 were exempted from work but unpaid. This current shutdown reflects deeper institutional challenges, including a narrow Republican majority in Congress, the absence of 60 Senate votes to overcome a filibuster, and a persistent partisan divide that has made bipartisan spending agreements difficult. The shutdown underscores the economic and human costs of political deadlock, with federal operations across all sectors suspended.
title: The last government shutdown was the longest in nearly 50 years. Here are all the recent shutdowns in one chart
